_comment: Created by ianb on 29/05/2014 14:52:34 using v2.1
analysis_commentary:
It was suggested that we should see a reduction in the proportion of those waiting over 52 weeks for treatment and an increase in the proportion of those being treated within 18 weeks (the two measures used) since April 2013.

Here, we see the proportion of people waiting the longest (more than 52 weeks) has been consistently small (under 0.3%) since April 2009 for admitted and non-admitted patients. The proportion of patients with an incomplete pathway waiting over 52 weeks has been falling steadily and has been below 0.05% since October 2012. We do see however an increase in the proportion of admitted pathways waiting more than 52 weeks since January 2014 - it was 0.09% in March 2014. There has been no noticeable effect on this trend from the introduction of the 'zero-tolerance' policy introduced in April 2013.
